citation.article-title: Description of Bacillus azotoformans sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Bacillus azotoformans sp. nov.
Bacillus azotoformans (a.zoto.for.mans. French n. azote nitrogen; L. part. adj. formans forming; azotoformans nitrogen forming)
Bacillus azotoformans has (0.9 to 1 by 3 to 10 μm), have rounded ends, and are rapidly motile by means of numerous long peritrichous flagella.
Gram reaction negative.
Gram type positive.
The cells have thick walls, mesosomes, and persistent septa.
Aminopeptidase is absent.
The endospores of this organism are oval (1.4 by 2 to 2.5 μm) and make the sporangium bulge; the spores are located terminally or subterminally.
Exosporium lacking.
Colonies are circular with entire margins, convex, and partially translucent, attaining a diameter of 5 mm on yeast extract-salts agar.
Growth is rapid and produces uniform and dense turbidity in yeast extract-salts liquid medium.
Poly-β-hydroxybutyrate
is produced when cells are grown in the presence of DL-3-hydroxybutyrate.
Chemoorganotrophic.
Growth factors are required.
Aerobic metabolism.
Glucose is neither fermented nor oxidized.
The following respiratory electron acceptors are utilized anaerobically; NO3-, NO2-, N2O, S4O6-, and fumarate.
S2O32- is not utilized as an electron acceptor.
Considerable quantities of N2 are produced in the course of reduction of NO3-, NO2-, N2O.
Oxidase reaction positive.

The following enzymes and electron carriers are present: cytochromes b and c ; oxidase a + a3; nitrate reductase A; nitrite (NO2- → NO), nitric oxide (NO → N2O), nitrous oxide (N2O → N2O), tetrathionate (S4O6- → S2O32-), and fumarate reductases ; and L-glutamate dehydrogenase.
The following enzymes are not detected: catalase, thiosulfate reductase, arginine dihydrolase, L-phenylalanine deaminase, urease, and β-galactosidase .

The following tests are negative: hydrolysis of gelatin, starch, and Tween 80; growth at pH 5.6; growth in the presence of 5% NaCl, 8% KN03, 0.02% NaN3, and 0.001% lysozyme; Voges-Proskauer reaction; indole production; decomposition of tyrosine; production of brown pigment in tyrosine-containing media; decomposition of hippurate with production of benzoate; and conversion of glycerol to dihydroxyacetone.
The following organic acids are degraded: acetate, succinate, DL-lactate, pyruvate, L-malate, citrate, L-glutamate, and L-aspartate.
Propionate, glycolate, malonate, glutarate, tartrate, and glycine are not degraded.
The maximum growth temperature is between 42 and 46°C; no growth occurs at 4°C.
Lipids comprise 5.7 to 7.4% of total cell dry weight.
Phosphatidylethanolamine is the major phospholipid; cardiolipin and phosphatidylglycerol are also present.
The fatty acid composition is as follows: iso-C14, 15 to 30 mol%; n-C14, 2 to 5 mol%; iso-C15, 28 to 52 mol%; anteiso-C15, 16 to 20 mol%; n-C15, 0 to 1 mol% iso-C16, 5 to 8 mol%; n-C16, 2 to 6 mol%.
Guanine-plus-cytosine content of deoxyribonucleic acid: 39.8 ± 1.2 mol% (as determined by buoyant density in CsCl).
Habitat: soils.

Selective isolation can be performed by enrichment culture of pasteurized (10 min, 80°C) soil samples in media containing 1% Bacto-Peptone (Difco Laboratories, Detroit, Mich.) incubated at 32°C in an atmosphere of pure N2O.
Type strain: strain 1 (= ATCC 29788 = CCM 2849 = CIP R925).
